sentence: Preprints represented less than 1% of the total number of journal articles in the life sciences published in 2016 (Fig 1).
In 2023 the share of life science preprints had grown to 10.7% (Fig 1).
Within the first two months of the pandemic they comprised over 30% of the published COVID-19 research (Fig 2A).
Roughly 2–7% of COVID-19 journal articles published in 2020–2023 were preceded by a preprint (Fig 2B).
For example, it is possible to filter the search to return preprints only (Fig 3A).
Additional filters help find preprints that have been published as a journal article (Fig 3B), or have an associated review or evaluation (Fig 3C).
Preprints are labelled with a green ‘Preprint’ tag, both in search results (Fig 4A), and on the preprint page (Fig 4B).
The preprint page also displays a yellow banner indicating to the user that the record they are viewing is a preprint (Fig 4C).
Hovering over the question mark sign in the banner brings up additional clarification about preprints (Fig 4D).
All preprint versions can be accessed from the ‘Preprint version history’ drop down (Fig 4E).
Version distribution for preprints in Europe PMC is shown in Fig 5.
The link to the journal article is displayed in the yellow warning banner for all preprint versions (Fig 6A).
In turn, the blue information banner on the journal article page provides a link to the latest preprint version (Fig 6B).
For example, 22% preprints posted in 2023 have been published, in comparison to 62% of preprints posted in 2013 (Fig 6C).
In Europe PMC, removed and withdrawn preprints are clearly labelled with a red warning banner (Fig 7A and 7B).
The same banner is also present on earlier versions if those exist in Europe PMC (Fig 7C).
This includes the preprint abstract and full text where available (Fig 8A).
Those tools are available within the navigation panel on the right (Fig 8B).
The navigation panel on the left (Fig 8C) provides access to related content.
Preprint review status is disclosed in the yellow warning banner (Fig 9A and 9B).
For earlier preprint versions it is also shown in the version history (Fig 9C).
Where available, Europe PMC shows evaluation date, review title or type, and evaluator name (Fig 9D).
For example, Europe PMC displays modified banners for preprints from Open Research Platforms (Fig 9B).
Figure 2 and lines 90-91: The numbers were higher than 30 only for the first two months, so it would be more precise to replace “few” with “two”.
This way the conversion of preprints to journal articles becomes more apparent and complements the analysis in Fig. 6.

Figure 5: add the percentage above each bar.
* References
Cabanac, G., Oikonomidi, T., & Boutron, I. (2021).

Regarding your note on percentage changes when running the code - this is indeed due to database updates. 
- Figure 2 and lines 90-91: The numbers were higher than 30 only for the first two months, so it would be more precise to replace “few” with “two”.
This way the conversion of preprints to journal articles becomes more apparent and complements the analysis in Fig. 6.
Thank you for your suggestion to depict the number of journal articles based on a preprint in Figure 2.

At present there is no extra space in the term ‘Covid-19’ on the line 1028.
- Figure 5: add the percentage above each bar.

We did not add percentages to the bars in Figure 5, as the graph only displays the number of preprint records that have more than one version in Europe PM

Roughly 2–7% of COVID-19 journal articles published in 2020–2023 were preceded by a preprint (Fig 2B).
For example, it is possible to filter the search to return preprints only (Fig 3A).
Additional filters help find preprints that have been published as a journal article (Fig 3B), or have an associated review or evaluation (Fig 3C).
Preprints are labelled with a green ‘Preprint’ tag, both in search results (Fig 4A), and on the preprint page (Fig 4B).
The preprint page also displays a yellow banner indicating to the user that the record they are viewing is a preprint (Fig 4C).
Hovering over the question mark sign in the banner brings up additional clarification about preprints (Fig 4D).
All preprint versions can be accessed from the ‘Preprint version history’ drop down (Fig 4E).
Version distribution for preprints in Europe PMC is shown in Fig 5.
The link to the journal article is displayed in the yellow warning banner for all preprint versions (Fig 6A).
In turn, the blue information banner on the journal article page provides a link to the latest preprint version (Fig 6B).
For example, 22% preprints posted in 2023 have been published, in comparison to 62% of preprints posted in 2013 (Fig 6C).
In Europe PMC, removed and withdrawn preprints are clearly labelled with a red warning banner (Fig 7A and 7B).
The same banner is also present on earlier versions if those exist in Europe PMC (Fig 7C).
This includes the preprint abstract and full text where available (Fig 8A).
Those tools are available within the navigation panel on the right (Fig 8B).
The navigation panel on the left (Fig 8C) provides access to related content.
Preprint review status is disclosed in the yellow warning banner (Fig 9A and 9B).
For earlier preprint versions it is also shown in the version history (Fig 9C).
Where available, Europe PMC shows evaluation date, review title or type, and evaluator name (Fig 9D).
